+modelmajorpita At the heart of the issue isn't straight time vs. overtime, 
its really Salary vs. Hourly pay. The argument that all this work can be 
done by off-the-street part time minimum wagers doesn't hold water. That 
works for much of it but that behavior isn't what this is about - there are 
instances where they want a specific worker there for more than 40 hours in 
a week, and locking them into a salary is the cheapest avenue to do that 
because they can wave a title and 25k gross salary in front of a part time 
worker making 12k gross a year and it seems like an offer that cannot be 
refused, until they realize that in exchange for taking on greater 
responsibilities they've really taken a pay *cut* vs. what they'd be making 
at their old hourly rate with the new longer hours.  So yes, in these cases 
it would actually be more expensive for the company to pay straight time to 
people vs. the set up that is being busted - Which is why several people 
have pointed out that your dystopian conclusion is actually pretty positive 
because if they did bring in more workers instead not only is a person not 
being screwed out of pay for hours worked, but unemployment would drop  - 
but the fact that isn't the cheapest route is what prevents it from 
happening now.

comments.text:
+Zach Taylor
What you're missing is bargaining power and leverage. Employers are often 
in a position to dictate terms to their employees. We have worker 
protection legislation, including the minimum wage and the 40-hour work 
week, because even though it does restrict freedom it results in better 
social outcomes because it restricts the ability of employers to exploit 
employees.

This is a crude solution with many hidden costs and drawbacks but it has 
been found effective at solving the perceived problem. We could discuss 
alternatives; for example a guaranteed basic income or citizen's dividend 
could in theory improve workers' bargaining positions to the point where 
many labour laws could be relaxed. But a pure libertarian-style free market 
too often allows employers to dictate unfavourable terms to employees.

yeah, i get it. too many people not enough jobs. I'm really just thinking 
out loud here.

The free market is like that. If you sell apples, but there are too many 
apple sellers and not enough apple buyers, then the cost of your apples has 
to go down. you need to make tough decisions, endure some hardships and do 
whatever you need to to keep your apple farm afloat. it's sad, but thats 
how the free market works. there is now an incentive for you to work 
harder, to be smarter, diversify your product listing, do something to get 
into a market that is less crowded. The free market "incentivises" hard 
work. The government does not go out and say "everyone making over $50,000 
a year has to buy $100 in apples a month". 

In this story, the workers are apple sellers. there are just too many of 
them. by free market principles they need to find a way to offer something 
more and that will result in them not having to get the government to tell 
the companies who pay them (apple buyers) how much to pay. the payers will 
observe the quality in their product and offer higher wages based on that.

If the government really wants to help, they should tax these companies 
more and invest in schools and community programs that will give these ppl 
more opportunities to learn skills that companies want and are willing to 
pay for....that is of course if you believe in a free market system

top_comment.author: Steven Calwas

comments.text:
"Every time TYT and others waste time responding to toxic Fox News 
propaganda, Fox News achieves their goal." 

I largely agree with this, save for one small detail.  The time addressing 
such talking points is "wasted", as you say, but largely because so many 
"others", collectively, are publishing them as a means of discussion. 

Depending on a given news organization, the decision to not spread or not 
address Fox News talking points may or may not have an impact on spreading 
it.  Each situation with each organization must be examined individually, 
based on the specifics of their situation. 

For example, if MSNBC decided to ignore all Fox News talking points, that 
might have a noticeable impact that Fox News would react to.  Thus, it is 
not just about the exclusively MSNBC audience or even the MSNBC audience 
that might also watch Fox News, but rather, it is also about the Fox News 
organization itself, and the Great Discussion at-large. 
Now, if a blatantly and unabashed progressive news organization decides to 
ignore Fox News talking points, that audience will still remain unaffected 
by the Fox News talking points, and Fox News would hardly notice or care, 
even if this unabashed news organization is very large. 
Depending on your interpretation, this might be a mildly positive or a 
mildly negative benefit for this non-Fox audience.  If you believe that 
this non-Fox audience is negatively susceptible to the Fox News talking 
points, then omitting them would be somewhat positive, but only mildly so 
as compared with a typical TV-news watcher.  On the other hand, this 
non-Fox audience might be largely immune to the deceptive populist wiles of 
Fox News, and thus they could only gain a benefit from a rebuttal analysis 
of the talking points, or at least bear neither benefit nor detriment from 
it. 

But, otherwise, you are mostly right in that, at least, Fox News is 
becoming decreasingly relevant these days...
Also, sometimes I just find them to be hilarious.  :-p

comments.text:
+Zach Taylor *:* *"Over-analyze much?"* lol, that's essentially my job. 

*"I only intended to say that you'll be paid according to what you 
contribute."* 
How do you measure contribution?  It's hard enough trying to figure out the 
value of a commodity, let alone something as abstract and intangible as 
"contribution." 

Markets are driven by self-interest, and so you have the self-interest of 
laborers seeking to get paid as much as possible, against the self-interest 
of employers who seek to maximize production while minimizing labor costs.  
In a perfect situation where all parties have all the information necessary 
to make a decision in a competitive labor market, you reach a natural 
"equilibrium" which serves as the basis of determining the true value of 
commodities in a free market. 

The competitiveness of the labor market can be measured, and depending on 
the area, it tends not to be particularly competitive.

Ultimately the result is a system where everyone is constantly trying to 
rip each other off, where one party tends to always have the upper hand.
comments.author: Proteus Avatár

comments.text:
+Proteus Avatár Over-analyze much? Of course the employer makes a profit. I 
only intended to say that you'll be paid according to what you contribute.
comments.author: Zach Taylor

comments.text:
+Zach Taylor *:* *"You'll get paid what you contribute"* 
lol, but that's not possible.  Laborers must be paid less than their worth 
and the product of their labor, in order for the employer to make a 
profit.  Labor markets which lack competition, suppress laborer bargaining 
power, and suffer from information asymmetries are not modeled well as 
"free markets."  Such markets tend to be horribly inefficient and can 
result in situations where people are human resources are wasted.  This 
results in ridiculous situations such as when a factory in some "factory 
town" closes down in order to move production overseas.  But neither the 
laid-off workers nor the physical factory go anywhere.  For a time, the 
factory retains all its original equipment because, typically, it is easier 
to contract out the work to some preexisting factory overseas. 

The equipment that they remove is typically sold off, but as it costs money 
to do this, as well as to properly dispose of unsold equipment, much of it 
stays in the factory and rots away. 
That is the height of inefficient use of human resources.  You have people, 
a means, and a desire, but the system just can't put it all together.  
That's the reality of Pareto non-optimal markets.

comments.text:
I think assuming that the worker has "failed" is the cause of overtime is 
an oversimplification of the issue.
It assumes that the employer in all cases allocates enough staff and 
resources in order to complete the jobs and also that the employer is able 
to predict changes in the workload due to local variances, like a rush of 
customers.
It also assumes there aren't any factors beyond the control of employers or 
employees, such as shortages of staff/skilled workers.
This is beyond the assumption of good faith on the part of the 
employers(i.e. they aren't intending to overwork/underpay workers to reduce 
costs)
The employees certainly can be at fault in some cases, but trying to label 
them always at fault is at best an oversimplification or at worst just 
wrong.

better off (more successful) for a number of reasons, and "hard work"

successful by taking series of calculated decisions and risks while being

instead of monetary compensation you are being "paid" in on-the-job

career, and helping you decide on an industry before you over-commit - all 
very important in 'white collar' fields. The guy that thinks simply

comments.text:
+Yves Baggi

@ fairness / good

O.k. wow … you opened some subject there – first of all fairness is not my 
ultimate target – I used the word „good“ because I did not want to start a 
debate about moral values …
However morality if it is about anything is about not harming other beings 
respectively helping them – in other words it is about the “well-being” of 
the members of a society. Those concept can be ultimately founded in 
reason. Assume a group of perfect reasonable beings making a contract about 
how to live in their society – they do not know what role they are going to 
have in that society – those perfect reasonable beings would necessarily 
agree on a perfect social contract – which content is founded objectively 
in reason and its value defined by those who are concerned – thus a social 
contract is not worse founded than most of our knowledge (except maybe 
mathematics or classical logic) …
Of course it is just a thought experiment and imperfect humans can never 
reach a perfect social contract but it demonstrates that such a contract in 
principial can have a sound foundation in reason.
So that was very briefly a bit of social contract moral theory. This is 
what I meant when I used the word fairness & good – excuse my sloppy 
language but I did not want to get into a discussion about a moral system.

@ State

I am not in favor of most things the state does! It only helps the richer 
class – it bails out banks for billions of dollars it helps the rich to 
safe taxes … the only thing it does since decades is attacking the poor ppl 
… how can you think I would appreciate anything the state does? The state 
is just a puppet of the rich class!

I am just saying I am in principial o.k. IF the state would regulate to 
achieve a better society (as defined above) – and if an economic system 
leads to children dying in coal mines I am all for intervention even if it 
means that some money has to be taken from the richer class – because there 
is a better way to organize our society for sure … on the other hand you 
would even accept dying children to protect the upper class …


Anyway: This discussion is already out of every border and I do not want to 
get into deep with all the topics you raised and also I do not want to be 
sloppy again …

Let me just say this –

I think I have demonstrated by simple mathematics that the possession of a 
large amount of money (e.g.: 1 billion [$]) more or less automatically 
leads to earning approximately 10 times more money every 50 years (assuming 
a real bad internal rate of return) that means after 50 years -> 10 billion 
after 100 years -> 100 billion after 150 years -> 1000 billion after 200 
years ->10.000 billion [$]

It is a fundamental problem of capitalism – as the goods and resources 
cannot grow with the same speed this money has to come from somewhere – 
either banks create it out of nowhere devaluating all the money you possess 
(btw. all the dollars an euros we have are not even worth the paper they 
are printed on anymore) or they take it directly by exploiting their 
employees or forcing the state to save money on e.g.: education (and 
therefore accepting the destruction of every society – because a society 
with bad education for all their kids is not competitive on the long run) 
or even go to war killing civilians to get oil (!).

Ultimately this system therefore collapses approximately every 50 years 
either in a huge war a revolution or the collapse of world economy …

And to be honest it is not that there is any disagreement here -literally 
everyone who has a glue of what he is talking agrees to that even just one 
example as you mentioned him – rich guys like Warren Buffet … you can read 
it in every history book and you can ask any economist …

Concerning the minimum vage example – of course the guy who works over time 
would earn more money afterwards as well – because as we agreed overtime 
should be paid …
But anyway don’t focus on specific examples – let’s say we find out (just 
accept it for the moment – for the sake of argument), that paying minimum 
wages is beneficial for the entire society (more money in the local economy 
more kids on college and university – more engineers and scientists … etc.) 
let’s say all of this works out that way – in that case would you be for it 
or not?
-> Because if yes than we ultimately have no disagreement
-> if no than we have an unresolvable disagreement
